description.dataset: Name of the dataset. The title needs to be short and easily recognizable and searchable. If there is an acronym, please also provide the long name.
description.experiment: Name of the experiment. The title needs to be short and easily recognizable and searchable. If there is an acronym, please also provide the long name.

The person(s) or organization(s) that contributed to the creation of the experiment. This can be the principal investigator, hospital, university, centre, clinic, etc. The first contact provided will be associated as the main contact for this experiment.

description.dataset: A short paragraph providing a rapid overview of the dataset and the context of data collection. Suggestion of items to include in the description (if applicable): main use of the dataset, population studied, study design, sample size, data collected, methods, techniques, apparatus used to generate the data. Ideally, the first sentence of the description should give a good overall description of the dataset.
description.experiment: A short paragraph providing a rapid overview of the experiment and the context of data collection. Suggestion of items to include in the description (if applicable): main procedure of the experiment, population studied, experimental design, data collected, methods, techniques, apparatus used to generate the outputs. Ideally, the first sentence of the description should give a good overall description of the experiment.

description.dataset: Terms to describe the nature of the data. Data type can be single or multiple. Add a term with the interlex URI if possible.
description.experiment: Terms to describe the nature of the data produced by the experiment (e.g., csv, audio recording, video recording). Data type can be single or multiple. Add a term with the interlex URI if possible.

description.dataset: Provide the version number, or the release point of your dataset. If you do not have an existing versioning convention, we recommend the use of the following versoning convention: 1.0=original dataset; 1.1=minor revisions made to the dataset; 1.2=further minor revisions; 2.0=major/substantive changes to the dataset. For example: minor changes could include corrupted file or link fixes, more description/documentation of the dataset and so on; Major changes would include additional data released (more subjects, more modalities and so on)
description.experiment: Provide the version number, or the release point of your experiment. If you do not have an existing versioning convention, we recommend the use of the following versoning convention: 1.0=original experiment; 1.1=minor revisions made to the experiment; 1.2=further minor revisions; 2.0=major/substantive changes to the experiment. For example: minor changes could include bug fixes, more description/documentation of the experiment and so on; Major changes would include additional experimental features (more stimuli or trials, more modalities and so on)

A qualifier to describe the data protection applied to the experiment. This is relevant for experimental stimuli taken from external sources.
  • open: freely and publicly available
  • registered: available to bona fide researchers/clinical care professionals only
  • controlled: available to qualified researchers approved by a committee after review of their research proposal; also known as managed or restricted access
  • private: available only to researchers of the project; also known as closed

The licences under which this experiment is shared. Note, this applies to the experimental files themselves and not the data that would be generated from the experiment. Visit Choose a License for more information on open-source licenses.

description.dataset: Tags associated with the dataset, which will help in its discovery. These should be well known terms by the research community.
description.experiment: Tags associated with the experiment, which will help in its discovery. These should be well known terms by the research community.
The technical format of the data generated from the experiment. Use the file extension or MIME type when possible. (Definition adapted from DataCite).
The quantity of space required on disk (or other medium) for this experiment.
Unit in which the size is measured.(KB -> KiloByte, MB -> MegaByte, GB -> GigaByte, TB -> TeraByte and PB -> PetaByte).
The information about access modality for the experiment distribution.

A URL (Web page) that contains information about the associated experiment (with a link to the experiment) or a direct link to the experiment itself. This could be a link to the GitHub, OSF, or Zenodo repository containing the experiment files, a lab website, or faculty page. When none exists yet, please enter "README.md."

Describe who can access the landing page. This must be one of "Public", "Registered" or "Private". When this field is absent the value will be treated as "Public". "Public" = available to anyone; "Registered" = available to user authorized by the creator; "Private" = available only to the creator.

description.dataset: Total number of files in the dataset.
description.experiment: Total number of files in the experiment.

description.dataset: Total number of subjects constituting the dataset.
description.experiment: Total number of subjects constituting the experiment. If not applicable, please put N/A.

The CONP status is used to add the CONP logo or Canadian flag on the left of the experiment and sorting in the data search. Valid values are "CONP" = created using funding from the CONP; "Canadian" = created in Canada without CONP funding; "external" = created outside of Canada.

Name of the institution or consortium that generated the experiment. Both an institution and a consortium can be specified, e.g. in the case of a named collaboration between different labs at the same institution.
Name of the institution where this experiment was created (if applicable).
Name of the consortium where this experiment was created (if applicable).
(Principal) city where this experiment was created.
(Principal) province where this experiment was created (if applicable).
(Principal) country where this experiment was created.
Required for derived experiments only. Provide information about the source experiment this experiment has been derived from.
Name of the source experiment used to generate this experiment.
Persistent identifier (e.g., DOI) of the source experiment used to generate this experiment.
The primary publication(s) associated with the experiment, usually describing how the experiment was produced.

primaryPublications.publicationVenue.name: Publication Venue
primaryPublications.publicationVenue.description: The name of the publication venue (e.g., journal) where the document is published (if applicable).

primaryPublications.dates.name: Dates
primaryPublications.dates.description: Relevant dates for the publication. If you provide a date, it must come with a description of the date (i.e.: first submission, final approval, date of publication, ...).

primaryPublications.identifier.name: Identifier
primaryPublications.identifier.description: A code uniquely identifying the publication locally to a system or globally. Provide a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) if you have one.

primaryPublications.identifier.identifie.name: Identifier Source
primaryPublications.identifier.identifie.description: Information about the organisation/namespace responsible for minting the identifier. It must be provided if the identifier is provided.

description.experiment: The different dimensions (granular components) making up a experiment. Providing dimensions give more details about the data types.
A code (e.g., digital object identifier, DOI) uniquely identifying the experiment locally to a system or globally.

identifier.identifierSource.name: Source
identifier.identifierSource.description: Information about the organisation/namespace responsible for minting the identifier. It must be provided if the identifier is provided.

logo.name: Logo
logo.description: Relative path and filename (e.g., logo.png, info/logo.jpg) containing the logo within the experimental files (recommended) or link to a URL for the logo.

description.experiment: Relevant dates for the experiment. If you provide a date, it must come with a description of the date (i.e.: version date, development start date, development end date, date of first publication, ...).
Provide contact information (name and email address) of the person responsible for the experiment.

description.dataset: Process which generated a given dataset.

description.experiment: Entities (biological entity, taxonomic information, disease, disease state, molecular entity, anatomical part, treatment) associated with this experiment. You must provide a species; other entities are optional.
Grant(s) which funded and supported the work reported by the experiment. Contributors to the experiment not listed as creators.
The geographical extension and span (i.e.: city, province, administrative region, ...) covered by the experiment.
In submitting this experiment for inclusion, I declare that I am not uploading any participant data and the only files included are those necessary to run the experiment.
One or more functions primarily assessed by the experiment. More detailed functions can be included as keywords in the General Info section.
One or more modalities (e.g. fMRI, EEG, MEG, behavioural) in which the experiment is performed.
Software required to run the experiment.
Software version required to run the experiment.
Device(s) the experiment can be run on (e.g. PC, tablet, smartphone, internet browser).
Operating system(s) the experiment can be run on (e.g. Windows, iOS, Linux).
Types of stimuli used for the experiment (e.g., audio, video, image).
Language(s) in which the experiment can be performed.
Validation measure(s) and population(s)
Accessibility considerations addressed during experimental development (e.g. colourblind friendly).
Any additional requirements for the experiment.
